00019 /**
00020  @page debian Running Debian GNU/Linux on OCTEON
00021 
00022 @section debian_intro 1. Introduction
00023 
00024     Debian is a very stable and well supported Linux distribution. From the
00025     Debian website (http://www.debian.org/) here is how they describe
00026     themselves:
00027 
00028 @verbatim
00029     Debian is a free operating system (OS) for your computer. An operating
00030     system is the set of basic programs and utilities that make your computer
00031     run. Debian uses the Linux kernel (the core of an operating system), but
00032     most of the basic OS tools come from the GNU project; hence the name
00033     GNU/Linux.
00034 
00035     Debian GNU/Linux provides more than a pure OS: it comes with over 15490
00036     packages, precompiled software bundled up in a nice format for easy
00037     installation on your machine.
00038 @endverbatim
00039 
00040     OCTEON runs the Debian GNU/Linux port for Mips processors <b>Debian 8.0</b>
00041     distribution from Debian's website.
00042 
00043     Quick links:
00044     - @ref debian_intro
00045     - @ref debian_kernel
00046     - @ref debian_cf
00047     - @ref debian_booting
00048     - @ref debian_networking
00049     - @ref debian_ssh
00050     - @ref debian_aptitude
00051     - @ref debian_o32
00052     - @ref debian_n32
00053     - @ref debian_cf_layout
00054     - @ref debian_customizations
00055     - @ref debian_bootlog
00056 
00057 @section debian_kernel 2. Building the Kernel
00058 
00059     A target has been added to the top level Linux makefile for building the
00060     kernel for Debian. The only difference from the standard Busybox based
00061     Linux is the absence of an initramfs filesystem. The commands below will
00062     build the Debian kernel.
00063 
00064 @verbatim
00065     $ cd ${OCTEON_ROOT}/linux
00066     $ make -s kernel-deb # The target "debian" will also work
00067 @endverbatim
00068 
00069     @note The Debian packages were built on a machine with 4KB pages. Although
00070     Debian will boot with other page sizes, some executables don't work
00071     properly. This will not affect binaries built with the Cavium toolchain,
00072     but O32 applications may have trouble. It is recommended you only run
00073     Debian with a 4KB page size.
00074 
00075 @section debian_cf 3. Setting up a Compact Flash
00076 
00077     Debian requires a more complicated compact flash layout than normal.
00078     Compact flash cards are normally formated with a single DOS FAT partition.
00079     For Debian, two partitions are need with two different filesystems
00080     (FAT and EXT3). The steps here will erase all data on the compact flash
00081     and reformat it for two partitions.
00082 
00083     - 1. Determine the device name for your compact flash reader/writer. When
00084         you plug the USB compact flash reader/writer into a USB port the Linux
00085         kernel will send information about it to the kernel log. After plugging
00086         in the reader/writer, use @b dmesg to view the log. Look for an entry
00087         similar to the one below near the end of the log. The device name is
00088         after the "Attached scsi removable disk". In this example, it is @b sda.
00089 @verbatim
00090         usb 1-2.4: new high speed USB device using address 22
00091         scsi17 : SCSI emulation for USB Mass Storage devices
00092           Vendor: ICSI      Model: IC1210        CF  Rev: 1.6F
00093           Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 02
00094         Attached scsi removable disk sda at scsi17, channel 0, id 0, lun 0
00095         Attached scsi generic sg0 at scsi17, channel 0, id 0, lun 0,  type 0
00096         USB Mass Storage device found at 22
00097 @endverbatim
00098 
00099     - 2. Add the following lines to @b /etc/fstab. Replace "sda" with the
00100         device name determined from above.
00101 @verbatim
00102         /dev/sda1       /mnt/cf1        auto    noauto,noatime,user     0 0
00103         /dev/sda2       /mnt/cf2        ext3    noauto,noatime,user     0 0
00104 @endverbatim
00105 
00106     - 3. Create mount points for the compact flash.
00107 @verbatim
00108         $ mkdir -p /mnt/cf1
00109         $ mkdir -p /mnt/cf2
00110 @endverbatim
00111 
00112     - 4. Setup a 1GB (or larger) compact flash with the Debian filesystem and
00113         kernel. Make sure OCTEON_ROOT is set properly, then execute @b make
00114         from the @b linux/debian directory. <b>All data on the flash will be
00115         erased.</b>
00116 @verbatim
00117         $ make DISK=/dev/sda compact-flash
00118 @endverbatim
00119 
00120     - 5. At this point the Debian filesystem is ready. These steps normally
00121         only need to be performed once. In the future, the kernel may be
00122         upgraded without affecting the rest of the filesystem by using the
00123         @b flash target of the top level Linux makefile.
00124 @verbatim
00125         $ cd ${OCTEON_ROOT}/linux
00126         $ make -s kernel-deb flash
00127 @endverbatim
00128 
00129 If you get an error message like the one below, be careful. This means the
00130 make script detect a disk device larger than 4GB. Compact flashes larger than
00131 4GB are very rare. More than likely you mistakenly told the script to format
00132 your <b>internal</b> hard drive. If you really want to install on a device
00133 larger than 4GB, you must manually remove the check from the Makefile.
00134 
00135 @verbatim
00136 **************************************************
00137 About to erase everything on /dev/sda.
00138 Disk /dev/sda: 74.3 GB, 74355769344 bytes
00139 You have 5 seconds to hit Control-C to stop this.
00140 **************************************************
00141 Refusing to destroy disk /dev/sda, larger than 4GB!
00142 @endverbatim
00143 
00144 @section debian_booting 4. Booting
00145 
00146     Once the compact flash is written, put it in the OCTEON board. The
00147     bootloader command to boot Debian is slightly different from the one used
00148     for the Busybox based filesystem. Debian requires the partition of the
00149     filesystem be passed to the kernel. The parameter <b>root=/dev/sda2</b>
00150     tells the kernel to find the root filesystem on partition 2 of the compact
00151     flash. It is recommended that you add a bootloader alias @b cfroot.
00152 @verbatim
00153     Octeon ebt5800# setenv cfroot 'fatload ide 0 $(loadaddr) vmlinux.64;bootoctlinux $(loadaddr) coremask=ffff root=/dev/sda2'
00154     Octeon ebt5800# saveenv
00155     Octeon ebt5800# run cfroot
00156 @endverbatim
00157 
00158     @note You can also add <b>mem=</b> to set the amount of memory
00159         (in megabytes) allocated to Linux. Setting it to 0 uses all available
00160         memory.
00161 
00162 @section debian_networking 5. Networking
00163 
00164     By default, the Debian system will attempt to configure eth0 (closest to
00165     the power switch) using DHCP. As part of the bootup messages it will
00166     display the address it receives from the DHCP server. Here is an example
00167     where OCTEON gets the IP address 192.168.16.166.
00168 
00169 @verbatim
00170     Listening on LPF/eth0/00:0f:b7:10:01:7a
00171     Sending on   LPF/eth0/00:0f:b7:10:01:7a
00172     Sending on   Socket/fallback/fallback-net
00173     DHCPDISCOVER on eth0 to 255.255.255.255 port 67 interval 3
00174     DHCPOFFER from 192.168.16.10
00175     DHCPREQUEST on eth0 to 255.255.255.255 port 67
00176     DHCPACK from 192.168.16.10
00177     bound to 192.168.16.166 -- renewal in 43200 seconds.
00178 @endverbatim
00179 
00180     OCTEON can be configure to use any of the available ethernet ports with
00181     either DHCP or a static IP address. The file @b /etc/network/interfaces
00182     controls how Debian configures the ports. For more information on this
00183     file, do a <b>man interfaces</b>.
00184 
00185 @section debian_ssh 6. Using SSH and SCP
00186 
00187     The Debian system starts OpenSSH. It can be used to login and copy files
00188     to/from another unix machine. Note that the default OpenSSH configuration
00189     blocks access to accounts with empty passwords. This means that before you
00190     can use OpenSSH, you must set a password for the @b root account. Login
00191     using the serial port and issue @b passwd to set the root password. After
00192     this you can use @b ssh and @b scp to access OCTEON.
00193 @verbatim
00194     $ ssh root@<OCTEON ip address>
00195     $ scp file root@<OCTEON ip address>:
00196 @endverbatim
00197 
00198     It is recommended that you use a ssh connection as your primary login
00199     method. Many applications expect more screen control than normally is
00200     available through a serial console. @b ssh from another Linux box will
00201     supply a better terminal emulation than Minicom.
00202 
00203 @section debian_aptitude 7. Installing Software
00204 
00205     Debian supports a huge package repository, the largest of any Linux
00206     distribution. Most any of these packages can be easily installed on
00207     OCTEON using the Debian package management system. The preferred interface
00208     to the package system is @b aptitude. Aptitude support both a command line
00209     interface as well as a curses based text GUI. For more detailed
00210     information, see the aptitude manual page. Below is a list of the most
00211     common keys needed in Aptitude.
00212 
00213     - ? - Short help on all of the keys
00214     - q - Exit current window. Exits Aptitude when the last window closes.
00215     - enter - Open a detailed information window about the selected item.
00216     - + - Mark the selected package for install
00217     - - - Mark the selected package for removal
00218     - L - Mark the selected package for reinstall
00219     - g - First display the changes that will be done, again to perform them
00220     - / - Search for a package
00221     - n - Continue a search
00222     - u - Update the package list for The Debian and Cavium Inc. web servers.
00223     - U - Upgrade any packages that have been changed by either Debian or Cavium Inc..
00224 
00225     The Debian package management system maintains a database of all
00226     packages. This database needs to be update periodically to make sure you
00227     are getting the latest version of packages. Hitting the <b>"u"</b> key, or
00228     issuing the command <b>"aptitude update"</b> will update this database.
00229     These commands do not affect the installed packages, they just update the
00230     database. A symptom that you need to update the database is that some
00231     packages aren't found when installing them. Database updates are not only
00232     pulled from the Debian servers, but also Cavium's Debian repository. The
00233     Cavium repository has modified packages for OCTEON support that add to or
00234     replace parts of the Debian system.
00235 
00236     Aptitude automatically handles all dependencies for a package. This makes
00237     it almost trivial to install very complicated packages. For example, to
00238     install Apache and start it serving web pages is simply:
00239 
00240 @verbatim
00241     $ aptitude install apache
00242 @endverbatim
00243 
00244 @section debian_o32 8. Compiling using the Debian Toolchain
00245 
00246     The Debian toolchain is installed and in the PATH by default. This
00247     toolchain builds code with the O32 ABI and without any Cavium Inc.
00248     optimizations. This is the compiler to use for anything using the standard
00249     Debian libraries (/lib). Applications supporting auto configure and auto
00250     make should "just work". In general, <b>this compiler should not be
00251     used</b>. The OCTEON specific compilers supplied by Cavium generate
00252     much better code.
00253 
00254     Results for "gcc -v":
00255     - Debian compiler: gcc version 4.9.2 (Debian 4.9.2-10)
00256     - Cavium compiler: gcc version 4.7.3 (Cavium Inc. Version: XXX)
00257 
00258 @section debian_n32 9. Compiling using the OCTEON Optimized Toolchain
00259 
00260     A Cavium Inc. optimized compiler is installed under
00261     /usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools. This compiler builds code for
00262     either the N64 or the N32 ABI. Although code generated by this compiler
00263     cannot use the Debian libraries, it can execute seamlessly alongside the
00264     rest of the system. This toolchain should be used for application using
00265     OCTEON specific hardware. To use this compiler, set your PATH to find it
00266     before the Debian default.
00267 
00268     @b N64
00269 @verbatim
00270         $ export PATH=/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools/usr/bin:${PATH}
00271         $ gcc -v
00272 @endverbatim
00273 
00274     @b N32
00275 @verbatim
00276         $ export PATH=/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools/usr/bin32:${PATH}
00277         $ gcc -v
00278 @endverbatim
00279 
00280     After setting your PATH, verify that the correct compiler is truly
00281     being used with "gcc -v".  Specifically, check the vendor string
00282     that is part of the version information:
00283 
00284     - Debian compiler: gcc version ... (Debian ...)
00285     - Cavium compiler: gcc version ... (Cavium Inc. ...)
00286 
00287     The compiler in @b bin32 is actually the same as in @b bin. The Mips
00288     option <b>-mabi=n32</b> is passed automatically to as, gcc, and g++ in
00289     order to force the compiler to build N32 code.
00290 
00291 @section debian_cf_layout 10. Compact Flash Layout
00292 
00293     The Debian compact flash is organized as two PC style partitions. The
00294     first partition is used for the kernel image <b>vmlinux.64</b>. This
00295     partition is used by the bootloader, so it uses the FAT16 filesystem
00296     (vfat under Linux). The second partition is an EXT3 filesystem containing
00297     the root filesystem for Debian. This partition can't be accessed from the
00298     bootloader.
00299 
00300 <table>
00301     <tr>
00302         <th>Partition</th>
00303         <th>Size</th>
00304         <th>Filesystem</th>
00305         <th>Debian Mount</th>
00306         <th>Host Mount</th>
00307         <th>Description</th>
00308     </tr>
00309     <tr>
00310         <td>0</td>
00311         <td>64MB</td>
00312         <td>vfat</td>
00313         <td>/boot</td>
00314         <td>/mnt/cf1</td>
00315         <td>Kernel and files for the Bootloader</td>
00316     </tr>
00317     <tr>
00318         <td>1</td>
00319         <td>500MB+</td>
00320         <td>ext3</td>
00321         <td>/</td>
00322         <td>/mnt/cf2</td>
00323         <td>Debian root filesystem</td>
00324     </tr>
00325 </table>
00326 
00327 @section debian_customizations 11. OCTEON Customizations to Debian
00328 
00329     For those interested in the exact changes made to Debian for OCTEON, the
00330     makefile "Makefile.debootstrap" shows the process of bootstrapping the
00331     OCTEON version of Debian. Currently there are three changes incorporated
00332     into this distribution not found in the standard Debian distribution.
00333 
00334     -# Linux threads weak ordering support.
00335             glibc-linuxthreads was modified to preform the proper "sync"
00336             instructions during locks and atomic operations.
00337     -# OCTEON support in oprofile.
00338             The standard oprofile package from Debian does not support Mips.
00339             Oprofile version 0.9 with support for OCTEON performance counters
00340             was added to the distribution.
00341     -# OCTEON optimized toolchain.
00342             In addition to the normal Debian gcc and binutils, an OCTEON
00343             optimized version has been installed under /usr/local/Cavium_Networks.
00344             The support libraries for this toolchain are symbolically linked
00345             to /lib32, /lib64, /usr/lib32, and /usr/lib64.
00346             OCTEON II optimized toolchain are under /lib32/octeon2, lib64/octeon2,
00347             usr/lib32/octeon2, and /usr/lib64/octeon2. OCTEON III optimized
00348             toolchain are under /lib32/octeon3, lib64/octeon3, /usr/lib32/octeon3
00349             and /usr/lib64/octeon3 directory.
00350
